questions.question: What is the relationship between the bandwidth of a signal and the width of its Fourier Transform?

answers.a: The bandwidth is inversely proportional to the width of the Fourier Transform.
answers.b: The bandwidth is directly proportional to the width of the Fourier Transform.
answers.c: The bandwidth is unaffected by the Fourier Transform.
answers.d: The bandwidth is related to the phase spectrum of the Fourier Transform.

explanations.a: This is incorrect. The relationship is direct, not inverse.
explanations.b: Correct! The bandwidth of a signal is directly proportional to the width of its Fourier Transform.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform affects the bandwidth of the signal.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; the bandwidth is related to the magnitude spectrum, not the phase.

questions.question: What is the Fourier Transform of a Gaussian pulse \( g(t) = e^{-\alpha t^2} \)?

explanations.a: Correct! The Fourier Transform of a Gaussian pulse results in another Gaussian function.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; sinc functions arise from rectangular pulses, not Gaussian pulses.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform of a Gaussian pulse is not an exponential function.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; a delta function is not the Fourier Transform of a Gaussian pulse.

questions.question: If a signal \( x(t) \) has a Fourier Transform \( X(f) \), what is the Fourier Transform of \( x(t) \cdot e^{j 2 \pi f_0 t} \)?

answers.a: The Fourier Transform is \( X(f - f_0) \).
answers.b: The Fourier Transform is \( X(f + f_0) \).
answers.d: The Fourier Transform is \( X(f) \cdot e^{j 2 \pi f_0 t} \).

explanations.a: Correct! Multiplying a signal by a complex exponential in the time domain shifts its Fourier Transform in the frequency domain.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; the shift is \( f - f_0 \), not \( f + f_0 \).
explanations.c: This is incorrect; the multiplication by a complex exponential causes a frequency shift.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; multiplying by a complex exponential introduces a frequency shift, not a direct multiplication.

questions.question: What is the Fourier Transform of a triangular pulse of width \( T \)?

explanations.a: Correct! The Fourier Transform of a triangular pulse results in a sinc function.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; Gaussian functions are not related to triangular pulses.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform of a triangular pulse is not another triangular pulse.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform of a triangular pulse is a sinc function, not its square.

questions.question: What is the effect of frequency scaling on the Fourier Transform of a signal?

answers.a: The Fourier Transform is scaled by the same factor.
answers.b: The Fourier Transform is scaled by the reciprocal of the scaling factor.
answers.c: The Fourier Transform is shifted in frequency by the scaling factor.

explanations.a: This is incorrect; the scaling in the frequency domain is not straightforward.
explanations.b: Correct! Frequency scaling in the time domain results in an inverse scaling in the Fourier domain.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; frequency scaling does not shift the Fourier Transform.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; scaling in the time domain affects the Fourier Transform.

questions.question: What is the Fourier Transform of a Dirac delta function \( \delta(t) \)?

explanations.a: Correct! The Fourier Transform of a Dirac delta function is a constant function.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; sinc functions are related to rectangular pulses, not delta functions.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform of a Dirac delta function is not another delta function.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; an impulse function is not the Fourier Transform of a Dirac delta function.

questions.question: What is the Fourier Transform of a signal \( x(t) \) sampled at a rate \( f_s \)?

answers.a: The Fourier Transform is periodic with period \( f_s \).
answers.b: The Fourier Transform is continuous with no periodicity.
answers.c: The Fourier Transform has a frequency shift by \( f_s \).
answers.d: The Fourier Transform is a sinc function.

explanations.a: Correct! The Fourier Transform of a sampled signal is periodic with a period equal to the sampling rate \( f_s \).
explanations.b: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform of a sampled signal is periodic.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; there is no frequency shift by \( f_s \).
explanations.d: This is incorrect; the Fourier Transform is not necessarily a sinc function.

questions.question: What happens to the Fourier Transform of a signal when the signal is convolved with a filter in the time domain?

answers.a: The Fourier Transform of the signal is multiplied by the Fourier Transform of the filter.
answers.b: The Fourier Transform of the signal is shifted in frequency.
answers.c: The Fourier Transform is unaffected by convolution.
answers.d: The Fourier Transform of the signal is convolved with the Fourier Transform of the filter.

explanations.a: Correct! Convolution in the time domain corresponds to multiplication in the frequency domain.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; convolution in the time domain does not cause a frequency shift.
explanations.c: This is incorrect; convolution in the time domain does affect the Fourier Transform.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; multiplication in the frequency domain corresponds to convolution in the time domain.

questions.question: What is the Fourier Transform of a time-scaled signal \( x(at) \), where \( a \) is a constant?

answers.a: The Fourier Transform is scaled by \(  rac{1}{|a|} \).
answers.b: The Fourier Transform is scaled by \( a \).
answers.c: The Fourier Transform is unaffected by time-scaling.
answers.d: The Fourier Transform is shifted by a factor of \( a \).

explanations.a: Correct! Time-scaling by \( a \) scales the Fourier Transform by \(  rac{1}{|a|} \).
explanations.b: This is incorrect; the scaling is by the reciprocal of \( a \).
explanations.c: This is incorrect; time-scaling does affect the Fourier Transform.
explanations.d: This is incorrect; time-scaling does not cause a shift in the Fourier Transform.

questions.question: What is the effect of multiplying a signal by a complex exponential \( e^{j 2\pi f_0 t} \) on its Fourier Transform?

answers.a: It shifts the Fourier Transform by \( f_0 \).
answers.b: It scales the Fourier Transform by \( f_0 \).
answers.c: It shifts the Fourier Transform by \( -f_0 \).
answers.d: It does not affect the Fourier Transform.

explanations.a: This is incorrect; the shift in the frequency domain is in the opposite direction.
explanations.b: This is incorrect; multiplication by a complex exponential does not scale the Fourier Transform.
explanations.c: Correct! Multiplying a signal by a complex exponential in the time domain shifts its Fourier Transform by \( -f_0 \).
explanations.d: This is incorrect; multiplication by a complex exponential causes a frequency shift.
